title: Photoelectric - determine e and work function

content.question:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

In Experiment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, students are asked to use a graph to determine the charge of an electron. Two metal plates are connected to a power supply of variable, known emf <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>. The plates are inside and on opposite sides of a vacuum-filled chamber. Electromagnetic radiation is incident to one plate. This results in the ejection of electrons from the plate. Ejected electrons move toward the other plate, as shown. The students also have access to an ammeter and a device that emits electromagnetic radiation of variable, known wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>. The device emits only one wavelength of electromagnetic radiation at a time.

(a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that would allow the students to use a graph to determine the charge of an electron. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.

frqParts.text:
Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight.

In Experiment <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>, students are asked to use a graph to determine the charge of an electron. Two metal plates are connected to a power supply of variable, known emf <math alttext="script uppercase E" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>Ɛ</mi></math>. The plates are inside and on opposite sides of a vacuum-filled chamber. Electromagnetic radiation is incident to one plate. This results in the ejection of electrons from the plate. Ejected electrons move toward the other plate, as shown. The students also have access to an ammeter and a device that emits electromagnetic radiation of variable, known wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math>. The device emits only one wavelength of electromagnetic radiation at a time.

(a) Describe a procedure for collecting data that would allow the students to use a graph to determine the charge of an electron. Include any steps necessary to reduce experimental uncertainty.
(b) Describe how the collected data could be graphed and how that graph would be analyzed to determine the charge of an electron.

In Experiment <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, students are asked to use a graph to determine the work function <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ϕ</mi></math> of a metal plate. In each trial, electromagnetic radiation is incident to the plate. This results in the ejection of electrons from the plate. The wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> of the electromagnetic radiation and the maximum kinetic energy <math alttext="K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi></math> of electrons ejected from the plate are determined in each trial. The table provides the collected data.
<math alttext="lambda, in nanometers" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>nm</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="K, in electron volts" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>K</mi><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mtext>eV</mtext></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math><math alttext="200" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>200</mn></math><math alttext="4.3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4.3</mn></math><math alttext="250" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>250</mn></math><math alttext="2.9" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.9</mn></math><math alttext="300" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>300</mn></math><math alttext="2.0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2.0</mn></math><math alttext="350" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>350</mn></math><math alttext="1.6" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.6</mn></math><math alttext="400" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>400</mn></math><math alttext="1.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.1</mn></math>
(c)

i. Indicate two quantities, either measured quantities from the table or additional calculated quantities, that could be graphed to produce a straight line that could be used to determine <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ϕ</mi></math>.

Vertical axis: __________          Horizontal axis: __________
Use the remaining columns in the table, as needed, to record any quantities indicated that are not already provided in the table. Label each column and include units as appropriate.

ii. On the grid provided, create a graph of the quantities indicated in part (c)(i).

Use the table to record the measured or calculated quantities that you will plot.

Clearly label the axes, including units as appropriate.

Plot the points you recorded in the table.
iii. Draw a best-fit line for the data graphed in part (c)(ii).
(d) Calculate <math alttext="phi" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>ϕ</mi></math> from the best-fit line that you drew in part (c)(iii).

skill.text: 1.B: Create quantitative graphs with appropriate scales and units, including plotting data.
